Dimensions.Description: This dimension ensures that all knowledge produced in the entire SLR lifecycle is managed, i.e., created, shared, reused, adapted, and eliminated.

keyPractices.description: Provide basis for the paper on actual research

textPassages.text: Is the paper based on research?
textPassages.study_title: Quality assessment of systematic reviews in software engineering: a tertiary study
textPassages.study_authors: Zhou,  You and Zhang,  He and Huang,  Xin and Yang,  Song and Babar,  Muhammad Ali and Tang,  Hao

practiceInstances.description: Maintain references accurately

textPassages.text: Are references maintained accurately?
textPassages.study_title: Quality assessment of systematic reviews in software engineering: a tertiary study
textPassages.study_authors: Zhou,  You and Zhang,  He and Huang,  Xin and Yang,  Song and Babar,  Muhammad Ali and Tang,  Hao

keyPractices.description: Make the data generated while conducting SLR available

practiceInstances.description: Make quality assessment data available for synthesis in systematic reviews

textPassages.text: Should the academic community also support the principle of making detailed data available for synthesis in a systematic review? We believe that it should, at the very least insofar as quality assessment is part of the systematic review process.
textPassages.study_title: Experiences Using Systematic Review Guidelines
textPassages.study_authors: Staples,  Mark and Niazi,  Mahmood

practiceInstances.description: Make data supporting reported claims available upon request for synthesis in systematic reviews

textPassages.text: We would support a call for a principle of academic research that data supporting claims made in a report or paper should be made available by researchers upon request, for synthesis in systematic reviews.
textPassages.study_title: Experiences Using Systematic Review Guidelines
textPassages.study_authors: Staples,  Mark and Niazi,  Mahmood

keyPractices.description: Take as baseline good SLR examples, experiences, and protocols from other researchers

textPassages.text: Find and read good SLR examples, experiences, and protocols from others as many as you can.
textPassages.study_title: Systematic literature reviews in software engineering: Preliminary results from interviews with researchers
textPassages.study_authors: Babar,  Muhammad Ali and Zhang,  He

keyPractices.description: Share the protocols within community

textPassages.text: Share the protocols within community
textPassages.study_title: Systematic literature reviews in software engineering: Preliminary results from interviews with researchers
textPassages.study_authors: Babar,  Muhammad Ali and Zhang,  He

keyPractices.description: Record all relevant information during the review process

textPassages.text: Do bookkeeping, record as much as you can during the review
textPassages.study_title: Systematic literature reviews in software engineering: Preliminary results from interviews with researchers
textPassages.study_authors: Babar,  Muhammad Ali and Zhang,  He

Dimensions.Description: This dimension ensures that researchers adopted adequate resources (frameworks, methods, tools, guidelines, checklists) to ensure SLR quality and effectiveness.

keyPractices.description: Adopt support resources that are adequate for the researcher's experience

practiceInstances.description: GRADE is not recommended for new researchers

textPassages.text: GRADE is a complicated approach and may be difficult for new SLR researchers.
textPassages.study_title: Quality assessment of systematic reviews in software engineering: a tertiary study
textPassages.study_authors: Zhou,  You and Zhang,  He and Huang,  Xin and Yang,  Song and Babar,  Muhammad Ali and Tang,  Hao

keyPractices.description: Select and apply a well-established guideline for SLR process

textPassages.text: Overall we recommend the guidelines
textPassages.study_title: Experiences Using Systematic Review Guidelines
textPassages.study_authors: Staples,  Mark and Niazi,  Mahmood

keyPractices.description: Use targeted collaborative tools to detect and resolve inter-rater reliability problems early
Use tools to appraise the quality of experiments in primary studies (when applicable)

practiceInstances.description: Use the checklist to appraise quality of experiments

textPassages.text: Kitchenham proposes a Generic Quality Checklist for Quality of Experiments (Table 3)
textPassages.study_title: An Evaluation of Quality Checklist Proposals - A participant-observer case study
textPassages.study_authors: Kitchenham,  Barbara A. and Brereton,  O. Pearl and Budgen,  David and Li,  Zhi

Dimensions.Description: This dimension ensures that all processes to validate each process of SLR (e.g., scope definition, protocol definition, studies selection, data extraction, data synthesis).

keyPractices.description: Conduct data analysis rigorously

textPassages.text: Was the data analysis (collected) sufficiently rigorous?
textPassages.study_title: Quality assessment of systematic reviews in software engineering: a tertiary study
textPassages.study_authors: Zhou,  You and Zhang,  He and Huang,  Xin and Yang,  Song and Babar,  Muhammad Ali and Tang,  Hao

practiceInstances.description: Use control groups to compare treatments

textPassages.text: Was there a control group with which to compare treatments?
textPassages.study_title: Quality assessment of systematic reviews in software engineering: a tertiary study
textPassages.study_authors: Zhou,  You and Zhang,  He and Huang,  Xin and Yang,  Song and Babar,  Muhammad Ali and Tang,  Hao

practiceInstances.description: Account for negative factors such as result inconsistency in evidence strength

textPassages.text: This situation might ignore the negative effect of the factors like inconsistency of results that could make to the strength of the evidence.
textPassages.study_title: Quality assessment of systematic reviews in software engineering: a tertiary study
textPassages.study_authors: Zhou,  You and Zhang,  He and Huang,  Xin and Yang,  Song and Babar,  Muhammad Ali and Tang,  Hao

keyPractices.description: Develop strategies to design and apply quality assessment of primary studies

textPassages.text: Appropriate guidelines are required for devising quality assessment strategies
textPassages.study_title: Quality assessment of systematic reviews in software engineering: a tertiary study
textPassages.study_authors: Zhou,  You and Zhang,  He and Huang,  Xin and Yang,  Song and Babar,  Muhammad Ali and Tang,  Hao

textPassages.text: Hence, it is important that SLRs researchers start paying more attention to the quality assessment of the papers included in SLRs.
textPassages.study_title: Quality assessment of systematic reviews in software engineering: a tertiary study
textPassages.study_authors: Zhou,  You and Zhang,  He and Huang,  Xin and Yang,  Song and Babar,  Muhammad Ali and Tang,  Hao

textPassages.text: Researchers have also emphasized the need for providing appropriate advice on how to assess the quality of primary studies as the quality of the results of a systematic review is largely dependent upon the quality of the primary studies reviewed., 11
textPassages.study_title: Systematic literature reviews in software engineering: Preliminary results from interviews with researchers
textPassages.study_authors: Babar,  Muhammad Ali and Zhang,  He

practiceInstances.description: Identify and reuse criteria to develop and apply quality assessment instruments for future SLRs

textPassages.text: For each aspect, researchers can gain the knowledge of the most concerned criteria, which is particularly helpful in developing and applying quality assessment instruments for future SLRs.
textPassages.study_title: Quality assessment of systematic reviews in software engineering: a tertiary study
textPassages.study_authors: Zhou,  You and Zhang,  He and Huang,  Xin and Yang,  Song and Babar,  Muhammad Ali and Tang,  Hao

textPassages.text: Select and tailor checklist items to create a quality checklist appropriate for the study
textPassages.study_title: An Evaluation of Quality Checklist Proposals - A participant-observer case study
textPassages.study_authors: Kitchenham,  Barbara A. and Brereton,  O. Pearl and Budgen,  David and Li,  Zhi

practiceInstances.description: Develop customized quality assessment checklists by adapting existing questions

textPassages.text: Systematic reviewers can form their own quality assessment checklists by selecting and revising several questions from the original questions
textPassages.study_title: Quality assessment of systematic reviews in software engineering: a tertiary study
textPassages.study_authors: Zhou,  You and Zhang,  He and Huang,  Xin and Yang,  Song and Babar,  Muhammad Ali and Tang,  Hao

textPassages.text: Discuss how to tailor checklists to specific research situations.
textPassages.study_title: An Evaluation of Quality Checklist Proposals - A participant-observer case study
textPassages.study_authors: Kitchenham,  Barbara A. and Brereton,  O. Pearl and Budgen,  David and Li,  Zhi

practiceInstances.description: Consult prior SLRs on similar topics to inform quality assessment criteria.

textPassages.text: If there exist any former SLRs on the similar topic, researchers may consult these SLRs in developing their criteria for quality assessment.
textPassages.study_title: Quality assessment of systematic reviews in software engineering: a tertiary study
textPassages.study_authors: Zhou,  You and Zhang,  He and Huang,  Xin and Yang,  Song and Babar,  Muhammad Ali and Tang,  Hao

practiceInstances.description: Incorporate credibility aspects into quality assessment criteria

textPassages.text: Our review has also found that there are not many SLRs whose quality assessment criteria pay sufficient attention to the credibility aspect in their quality assessment criteria.
textPassages.study_title: Quality assessment of systematic reviews in software engineering: a tertiary study
textPassages.study_authors: Zhou,  You and Zhang,  He and Huang,  Xin and Yang,  Song and Babar,  Muhammad Ali and Tang,  Hao

practiceInstances.description: Develop quality criteria aligned with assessment purpose, not blindly

textPassages.text: This information can help researchers to develop the quality criteria according to the purpose of their quality assessment: rather than ‘blindly’ performing the quality assessment for no particular reason.
textPassages.study_title: Quality assessment of systematic reviews in software engineering: a tertiary study
textPassages.study_authors: Zhou,  You and Zhang,  He and Huang,  Xin and Yang,  Song and Babar,  Muhammad Ali and Tang,  Hao

practiceInstances.description: Design quality assessment checklists using factors that could bias study results

textPassages.text: For detailed quality assessment, checklists can be designed using factors that could bias study results.
textPassages.study_title: Experiences Using Systematic Review Guidelines
textPassages.study_authors: Staples,  Mark and Niazi,  Mahmood

practiceInstances.description: Assess the quality of primary studies based on the type of systematic literature review undertaken

textPassages.text: All the medical standards emphasize that it is necessary to assess the quality of primary studies. However, it depends on the type of systematic literature review you are undertaking.
textPassages.study_title: Experiences Using Systematic Review Guidelines
textPassages.study_authors: Staples,  Mark and Niazi,  Mahmood

practiceInstances.description: Adopt a team-based process for quality checklist construction and provide guidance on answering checklist questions

textPassages.text: Researchers might find it useful to adopt a team-based process for quality checklist construction and provide suggestions for answering quality checklist questions.
textPassages.study_title: An Evaluation of Quality Checklist Proposals - A participant-observer case study
textPassages.study_authors: Kitchenham,  Barbara A. and Brereton,  O. Pearl and Budgen,  David and Li,  Zhi

practiceInstances.description: Include an item in quality assessment asking whether a sensitivity or stability analysis was performed

textPassages.text: Given that the quality checklist is intended to provide an assessment of whether the results of the primary study are trustworthy, we should include an item to ask whether the study had performed a sensitivity or stability analysis to ensure that the results were not a result of one or two abnormal values.
textPassages.study_title: An Evaluation of Quality Checklist Proposals - A participant-observer case study
textPassages.study_authors: Kitchenham,  Barbara A. and Brereton,  O. Pearl and Budgen,  David and Li,  Zhi

practiceInstances.description: Restrict the number of checklist items

textPassages.text: Restrict the number of checklist items. We suggest between 6 and 12.
textPassages.study_title: An Evaluation of Quality Checklist Proposals - A participant-observer case study
textPassages.study_authors: Kitchenham,  Barbara A. and Brereton,  O. Pearl and Budgen,  David and Li,  Zhi

practiceInstances.description: Balance the number of checklist items to ensure both correct evaluation and comprehensive coverage

textPassages.text: The fewer the items the more likely that they will be correctly evaluated, yet too few questions make it difficult to capture all the aspects of methodology quality.
textPassages.study_title: An Evaluation of Quality Checklist Proposals - A participant-observer case study
textPassages.study_authors: Kitchenham,  Barbara A. and Brereton,  O. Pearl and Budgen,  David and Li,  Zhi

textPassages.text: Suggesting some limits to quality checklist size in the guidelines
textPassages.study_title: An Evaluation of Quality Checklist Proposals - A participant-observer case study
textPassages.study_authors: Kitchenham,  Barbara A. and Brereton,  O. Pearl and Budgen,  David and Li,  Zhi

practiceInstances.description: Consider what information is needed to answer each checklist question

textPassages.text: Consider what information is needed to answer the checklist question.
textPassages.study_title: An Evaluation of Quality Checklist Proposals - A participant-observer case study
textPassages.study_authors: Kitchenham,  Barbara A. and Brereton,  O. Pearl and Budgen,  David and Li,  Zhi

practiceInstances.description: Request additional information from authors for questions about issues that are not reported

textPassages.text: Consider what information is needed to answer the checklist question. Questions relating to issues that are not usually reported will require asking the authors for details. Questions that are very subjective will not give reliable answers
textPassages.study_title: An Evaluation of Quality Checklist Proposals - A participant-observer case study
textPassages.study_authors: Kitchenham,  Barbara A. and Brereton,  O. Pearl and Budgen,  David and Li,  Zhi

practiceInstances.description: Remove overlapping checklist items

textPassages.text: Remove checklist items that overlap
textPassages.study_title: An Evaluation of Quality Checklist Proposals - A participant-observer case study
textPassages.study_authors: Kitchenham,  Barbara A. and Brereton,  O. Pearl and Budgen,  David and Li,  Zhi

practiceInstances.description: Concentrate on checklist items that assess whether results are valid

textPassages.text: Concentrate on checklist items related to whether the results are valid
textPassages.study_title: An Evaluation of Quality Checklist Proposals - A participant-observer case study
textPassages.study_authors: Kitchenham,  Barbara A. and Brereton,  O. Pearl and Budgen,  David and Li,  Zhi

practiceInstances.description: Avoid generic checklist items

textPassages.text:
"The exercise we undertook to construct a team-based quality checklist for our testing SLR suggested that the number of generic checklist items could be much reduced. Based on our team discussions, it would seem that the quality checklist shown in Table 3 would both reduce redundancies among items and remove items related to
reporting quality, leading to a much simpler generic checklist. "
textPassages.study_title: An Evaluation of Quality Checklist Proposals - A participant-observer case study
textPassages.study_authors: Kitchenham,  Barbara A. and Brereton,  O. Pearl and Budgen,  David and Li,  Zhi

textPassages.text: Refine any generic checklist to meet the specific requirements of the SLR.
textPassages.study_title: An Evaluation of Quality Checklist Proposals - A participant-observer case study
textPassages.study_authors: Kitchenham,  Barbara A. and Brereton,  O. Pearl and Budgen,  David and Li,  Zhi

practiceInstances.description: Trial quality checklists on a subset of primary studies, compare results, and refine items and evaluation processes

textPassages.text: That is, the quality checklists should be trialled on a subset of primary studies and the results compared and any disagreements discussed to refine both the quality checklists and the quality evaluation process.
textPassages.study_title: An Evaluation of Quality Checklist Proposals - A participant-observer case study
textPassages.study_authors: Kitchenham,  Barbara A. and Brereton,  O. Pearl and Budgen,  David and Li,  Zhi

practiceInstances.description: Use ordinal scales (e.g., not at all to fully) instead of simple Yes/No answers.

textPassages.text: The answers should probably be an ordinal scale (e.g. not at all, a little, somewhat, mostly, fully) rather than a simple Yes/No.
textPassages.study_title: An Evaluation of Quality Checklist Proposals - A participant-observer case study
textPassages.study_authors: Kitchenham,  Barbara A. and Brereton,  O. Pearl and Budgen,  David and Li,  Zhi

keyPractices.description: Address search & selection bias

practiceInstances.description: Integrate manual and automated search strategies

textPassages.text: In order to exhaustively identify SLRs with quality assessment component and ensure that the process of papers selection was unbiased as far as possible, the approach of quasi-gold standard (QGS) was adopted, which systematically integrates manual and automated search strategies and suggests a relatively rigorous approach for search performance evaluation in terms of sensitivity and precision.
textPassages.study_title: Quality assessment of systematic reviews in software engineering: a tertiary study
textPassages.study_authors: Zhou,  You and Zhang,  He and Huang,  Xin and Yang,  Song and Babar,  Muhammad Ali and Tang,  Hao

practiceInstances.description: Select and justify a search strategy appropriate for the research question.

textPassages.text: There are alternative search strategies that enable you to achieve different sort of search completion criteria. You must select and justify a search strategy that is appropriate for your research question.
textPassages.study_title: Experiences Using Systematic Review Guidelines
textPassages.study_authors: Staples,  Mark and Niazi,  Mahmood

practiceInstances.description: Review conclusions as well as abstracts when selecting primary studies

textPassages.text: The standard of IT and software engineering abstracts is too poor to rely on when selecting primary studies. You should also review the conclusions.
textPassages.study_title: Experiences Using Systematic Review Guidelines
textPassages.study_authors: Staples,  Mark and Niazi,  Mahmood

practiceInstances.description: Use sensitivity analyses to determine the effect of excluding low-quality publications

textPassages.text: it is possible to perform sensitivity analyses to determine the effects on the synthesis results of ignoring low quality publications.
textPassages.study_title: Experiences Using Systematic Review Guidelines
textPassages.study_authors: Staples,  Mark and Niazi,  Mahmood

practiceInstances.description: Apply snowballing as a complementary search to avoid missing relevant studies

textPassages.text: ...we also used the snowballing as the complementary search to reduce the possibility of missing relevant SLRs.
textPassages.study_title: Quality assessment of systematic reviews in software engineering: a tertiary study
textPassages.study_authors: Zhou,  You and Zhang,  He and Huang,  Xin and Yang,  Song and Babar,  Muhammad Ali and Tang,  Hao

keyPractices.description: Address publication bias

textPassages.text: the search strategy should attempt to address publication bias by trying to find publications that report negative results.
textPassages.study_title: Experiences Using Systematic Review Guidelines
textPassages.study_authors: Staples,  Mark and Niazi,  Mahmood

practiceInstances.description: Address publication bias in the search strategy by including studies with negative results

textPassages.text: the search strategy should attempt to address publication bias by trying to find publications that report negative results.
textPassages.study_title: Experiences Using Systematic Review Guidelines
textPassages.study_authors: Staples,  Mark and Niazi,  Mahmood

practiceInstances.description: Identify multiple reports of the same study and seek missing or unpublished data from authors

textPassages.text: multiple reports of the same study should be identified, and missing or unpublished data should be sought from the publications’ authors.
textPassages.study_title: Experiences Using Systematic Review Guidelines
textPassages.study_authors: Staples,  Mark and Niazi,  Mahmood

keyPractices.description: Follow the process described in the protocol

practiceInstances.description: Perform data extraction according to the systematic review protocol

textPassages.text: Data extraction should be performed as indicated in the systematic review protocol.
textPassages.study_title: Experiences Using Systematic Review Guidelines
textPassages.study_authors: Staples,  Mark and Niazi,  Mahmood

practiceInstances.description: Follow the selection process described in the protocol

textPassages.text: the selection process should follow the plan described in the protocol.
textPassages.study_title: Experiences Using Systematic Review Guidelines
textPassages.study_authors: Staples,  Mark and Niazi,  Mahmood

keyPractices.description: Address the researcher's bias

practiceInstances.description: Check the reliability of the selection process

textPassages.text: checking the reliability of this selection process, in order to reduce the risk of researcher bias.
textPassages.study_title: Experiences Using Systematic Review Guidelines
textPassages.study_authors: Staples,  Mark and Niazi,  Mahmood

keyPractices.description: Establish a validation process separate from protocol piloting

textPassages.text: There needs to be an agreed validation process separate from the protocol piloting activity.
textPassages.study_title: Experiences Using Systematic Review Guidelines
textPassages.study_authors: Staples,  Mark and Niazi,  Mahmood

keyPractices.description: Ensure that guidelines and quality checklists are accessible and appropriate for users with varying levels expertise

textPassages.text: It seems clear that the checklists by themselves are not helpful to novices
textPassages.study_title: An Evaluation of Quality Checklist Proposals - A participant-observer case study
textPassages.study_authors: Kitchenham,  Barbara A. and Brereton,  O. Pearl and Budgen,  David and Li,  Zhi

textPassages.text: The supervisors had mixed views about the checklists and some concern that the checklists would be difficult for non-statisticians or researchers inexperienced in empirical studies. One supervisor noted that the testing SLR is primarily a mapping SLR and thought the quality checklists were misleading for that type of study. Both supervisors reinforce the point made by the RA, that some statistical expertise is required to use the guidelines effectively and some terminology needs to be included in the guidelines
textPassages.study_title: An Evaluation of Quality Checklist Proposals - A participant-observer case study
textPassages.study_authors: Kitchenham,  Barbara A. and Brereton,  O. Pearl and Budgen,  David and Li,  Zhi

keyPractices.description: Advance beyond simply summarizing articles, evaluate their quality and relevance using explicit criteria

textPassages.text:
"“Instead of simply summarising the content of each article, try to evaluate them in order to decide whether they are good pieces of research and helpful to you and your research question.”
“Try to summarise & critically evaluate each article studied as well as synthesising the full collection.”"
textPassages.study_title: Preliminary Reporting Guidelines for Experience Papers
textPassages.study_authors: Budgen,  David and Zhang,  Cheng

Dimensions.Description: This dimension ensures that all the interactions among researchers and the target audience are well-performed.

keyPractices.description: Consider the researcher–participant relationship adequately

textPassages.text: Has the relationship between researcher and participants been considered to an adequate degree?
textPassages.study_title: Quality assessment of systematic reviews in software engineering: a tertiary study
textPassages.study_authors: Zhou,  You and Zhang,  He and Huang,  Xin and Yang,  Song and Babar,  Muhammad Ali and Tang,  Hao

keyPractices.description: Validate the approach in academia or industry

textPassages.text: Has the approach been validated on a certain scale (either in academia or/ and industry)?
textPassages.study_title: Quality assessment of systematic reviews in software engineering: a tertiary study
textPassages.study_authors: Zhou,  You and Zhang,  He and Huang,  Xin and Yang,  Song and Babar,  Muhammad Ali and Tang,  Hao

keyPractices.description: Develop strategies to search and select studies collaboratively

textPassages.text: In addition, the search strategy was developed by the three research students and reviewed by their supervisor.
textPassages.study_title: Quality assessment of systematic reviews in software engineering: a tertiary study
textPassages.study_authors: Zhou,  You and Zhang,  He and Huang,  Xin and Yang,  Song and Babar,  Muhammad Ali and Tang,  Hao

textPassages.text: Moreover, the cross-check was necessary among the reviewers, and again we had at least two research students extracting data from each selected SLR independently.
textPassages.study_title: Quality assessment of systematic reviews in software engineering: a tertiary study
textPassages.study_authors: Zhou,  You and Zhang,  He and Huang,  Xin and Yang,  Song and Babar,  Muhammad Ali and Tang,  Hao

textPassages.text: disagreements in selection should be discussed and resolved
textPassages.study_title: Experiences Using Systematic Review Guidelines
textPassages.study_authors: Staples,  Mark and Niazi,  Mahmood

practiceInstances.description: Check duplicates independently by at least two researchers to minimize bias

textPassages.text: To ensure the removal of these duplicates, each retrieved paper was checked and further read by at least two researchers independently to handle the duplication and limited bias as much as possible.
textPassages.study_title: Quality assessment of systematic reviews in software engineering: a tertiary study
textPassages.study_authors: Zhou,  You and Zhang,  He and Huang,  Xin and Yang,  Song and Babar,  Muhammad Ali and Tang,  Hao

textPassages.text: We assigned the workload to make sure that each study was checked by at least two researchers independently to minimize the potential impact of any bias.
textPassages.study_title: Quality assessment of systematic reviews in software engineering: a tertiary study
textPassages.study_authors: Zhou,  You and Zhang,  He and Huang,  Xin and Yang,  Song and Babar,  Muhammad Ali and Tang,  Hao

practiceInstances.description: Escalate unresolved disagreements to a supervisor

textPassages.text: Any disagreements that could not be solved were escalated to the supervisor.
textPassages.study_title: Quality assessment of systematic reviews in software engineering: a tertiary study
textPassages.study_authors: Zhou,  You and Zhang,  He and Huang,  Xin and Yang,  Song and Babar,  Muhammad Ali and Tang,  Hao

practiceInstances.description: Resolve disagreements on search and selection through joint discussion

textPassages.text: The disagreements on search and selection opinions were solved in joint discussion
textPassages.study_title: Quality assessment of systematic reviews in software engineering: a tertiary study
textPassages.study_authors: Zhou,  You and Zhang,  He and Huang,  Xin and Yang,  Song and Babar,  Muhammad Ali and Tang,  Hao

keyPractices.description: Perform cross-checks with reviewers (independent, supervisors, team-members) for data extraction

textPassages.text: The supervisor played the role of expert panel who dealt with any divergences and disagreements between the students during the process.
textPassages.study_title: Quality assessment of systematic reviews in software engineering: a tertiary study
textPassages.study_authors: Zhou,  You and Zhang,  He and Huang,  Xin and Yang,  Song and Babar,  Muhammad Ali and Tang,  Hao

practiceInstances.description: Perform data extraction by at least two researchers and resolve disagreements by consensus or additional reviewers

textPassages.text: Kitchenham recommends performing data extraction by two or more researchers and settling disagreements by consensus or by use of additional researchers.
textPassages.study_title: Experiences Using Systematic Review Guidelines
textPassages.study_authors: Staples,  Mark and Niazi,  Mahmood

practiceInstances.description: Assign one reader as data extractor and another as data checker when reviewing large numbers of papers

textPassages.text: Having one reader act as a data extractor and one act as data checker may be helpful when there are a large number of papers to review.
textPassages.study_title: Experiences Using Systematic Review Guidelines
textPassages.study_authors: Staples,  Mark and Niazi,  Mahmood

keyPractices.description: Involve all review team members in developing the protocol

textPassages.text: Review team members must make sure they understand the protocol and the data extraction process.
textPassages.study_title: Experiences Using Systematic Review Guidelines
textPassages.study_authors: Staples,  Mark and Niazi,  Mahmood

textPassages.text: All systematic review team members need to take an active part in developing the review protocol.
textPassages.study_title: Experiences Using Systematic Review Guidelines
textPassages.study_authors: Staples,  Mark and Niazi,  Mahmood

keyPractices.description: Construct quality checklists individually, then discuss similarities and differences to produce a team checklist

textPassages.text: We found the process of constructing quality checklists individually and then discussing the similarities and differences in order to produce a team checklist was very useful. We would recommend such a process to other researchers.
textPassages.study_title: An Evaluation of Quality Checklist Proposals - A participant-observer case study
textPassages.study_authors: Kitchenham,  Barbara A. and Brereton,  O. Pearl and Budgen,  David and Li,  Zhi

keyPractices.description: Provide feedback for students that includes forward-looking advice for improvement

textPassages.text: Such feedback should not just tell students what they have done well or poorly, but also “feed forward”, that is provide advice for how the students can improve in their next piece of work
textPassages.study_title: Preliminary Reporting Guidelines for Experience Papers
textPassages.study_authors: Budgen,  David and Zhang,  Cheng

keyPractices.description: Involve experienced SLR researchers for consultation and feedback

textPassages.text: Have somebody with experience in conducting SLRs involved or being in touch, make them available to consult to, and ask them check your questions and results
textPassages.study_title: Systematic literature reviews in software engineering: Preliminary results from interviews with researchers
textPassages.study_authors: Babar,  Muhammad Ali and Zhang,  He

Dimensions.Description: This dimension ensures that process documentation, consequently, the reproducibility and auditability is assured.

keyPractices.description: Ensure a clear statement of research aims and objectives

textPassages.text: Is there a clear statement (definition) of the aims (goals, purposes, problems, motivations, objectives, questions) of the research?
textPassages.study_title: Quality assessment of systematic reviews in software engineering: a tertiary study
textPassages.study_authors: Zhou,  You and Zhang,  He and Huang,  Xin and Yang,  Song and Babar,  Muhammad Ali and Tang,  Hao

keyPractices.description: Provide an adequate description of the context in which the research was conducted

textPassages.text: Is there an adequate description of the context in which the research was carried out?
textPassages.study_title: Quality assessment of systematic reviews in software engineering: a tertiary study
textPassages.study_authors: Zhou,  You and Zhang,  He and Huang,  Xin and Yang,  Song and Babar,  Muhammad Ali and Tang,  Hao

keyPractices.description: Describe data collection methods

textPassages.text: Are the data collection methods adequately described (defined)?
textPassages.study_title: Quality assessment of systematic reviews in software engineering: a tertiary study
textPassages.study_authors: Zhou,  You and Zhang,  He and Huang,  Xin and Yang,  Song and Babar,  Muhammad Ali and Tang,  Hao

keyPractices.description: Ensure the study presents the results and answers the research question in clear way

textPassages.text: Does the study answer the research question defined or presents the results in a clear way?
textPassages.study_title: Quality assessment of systematic reviews in software engineering: a tertiary study
textPassages.study_authors: Zhou,  You and Zhang,  He and Huang,  Xin and Yang,  Song and Babar,  Muhammad Ali and Tang,  Hao

textPassages.text: Clearly state findings and relate them to research aims.
textPassages.study_title: Quality assessment of systematic reviews in software engineering: a tertiary study
textPassages.study_authors: Zhou,  You and Zhang,  He and Huang,  Xin and Yang,  Song and Babar,  Muhammad Ali and Tang,  Hao

textPassages.text: Ensuring that questions selected can be answered and providing advice to make the answers as objective as possible.
textPassages.study_title: An Evaluation of Quality Checklist Proposals - A participant-observer case study
textPassages.study_authors: Kitchenham,  Barbara A. and Brereton,  O. Pearl and Budgen,  David and Li,  Zhi

practiceInstances.description: Validate and justify variables, metrics, and study design

textPassages.text: Are the variables/metrics/methods/design used in the study adequately measured and validated (justified)?
textPassages.study_title: Quality assessment of systematic reviews in software engineering: a tertiary study
textPassages.study_authors: Zhou,  You and Zhang,  He and Huang,  Xin and Yang,  Song and Babar,  Muhammad Ali and Tang,  Hao

practiceInstances.description: Explain how the information extracted answers the research questions

textPassages.text: Tabulating the data is a useful means of aggregation but it is necessary to explain how the aggregated data actually answers the research questions.
textPassages.study_title: Experiences Using Systematic Review Guidelines
textPassages.study_authors: Staples,  Mark and Niazi,  Mahmood

practiceInstances.description: Synthesize across studies to directly address the research question rather than presenting isolated summaries

textPassages.text: Be sure you have answered your own question. I couldn’t see how your analysis of the published research answered the question re evidence for making better computer programmers.
textPassages.study_title: Preliminary Reporting Guidelines for Experience Papers
textPassages.study_authors: Budgen,  David and Zhang,  Cheng

keyPractices.description: Discuss limitations and threats to validity

textPassages.text: Do the researchers discuss any problems (limitations, threats) with the validity (reliability) of their results?
textPassages.study_title: Quality assessment of systematic reviews in software engineering: a tertiary study
textPassages.study_authors: Zhou,  You and Zhang,  He and Huang,  Xin and Yang,  Song and Babar,  Muhammad Ali and Tang,  Hao

keyPractices.description: Present sufficient data to support findings

textPassages.text: Has sufficient data been presented to support the findings?
textPassages.study_title: Quality assessment of systematic reviews in software engineering: a tertiary study
textPassages.study_authors: Zhou,  You and Zhang,  He and Huang,  Xin and Yang,  Song and Babar,  Muhammad Ali and Tang,  Hao

textPassages.text: Are the findings credible?
textPassages.study_title: Quality assessment of systematic reviews in software engineering: a tertiary study
textPassages.study_authors: Zhou,  You and Zhang,  He and Huang,  Xin and Yang,  Song and Babar,  Muhammad Ali and Tang,  Hao

keyPractices.description: Report conclusions and implications appropriately for the audience

textPassages.text: Are conclusions, implications for practice and future research, reported suitably for its audience?
textPassages.study_title: Quality assessment of systematic reviews in software engineering: a tertiary study
textPassages.study_authors: Zhou,  You and Zhang,  He and Huang,  Xin and Yang,  Song and Babar,  Muhammad Ali and Tang,  Hao

keyPractices.description: Define and document the systematic review in a detailed protocol

textPassages.text: the procedures to be followed should be defined in the protocol.
textPassages.study_title: Experiences Using Systematic Review Guidelines
textPassages.study_authors: Staples,  Mark and Niazi,  Mahmood

practiceInstances.description: Define and document a search strategy as part of the protocol

textPassages.text: Definition and documentation of a search strategy as part of the protocol, to find as much of the relevant literature as possible.
textPassages.study_title: Experiences Using Systematic Review Guidelines
textPassages.study_authors: Staples,  Mark and Niazi,  Mahmood

practiceInstances.description: Define and document a systematic review protocol in advance

textPassages.text: Definition and documentation of a systematic review protocol in advance of conducting the review, to specify the research questions and the procedures to be used to perform the review.
textPassages.study_title: Experiences Using Systematic Review Guidelines
textPassages.study_authors: Staples,  Mark and Niazi,  Mahmood

textPassages.text: a pre-defined protocol is necessary to reduce the possibility of researcher bias.
textPassages.study_title: Experiences Using Systematic Review Guidelines
textPassages.study_authors: Staples,  Mark and Niazi,  Mahmood

practiceInstances.description: Describe explicit inclusion and exclusion criteria as part of the protocol

textPassages.text: Description of the explicit inclusion and exclusion criteria as part of the protocol, to be used to assess each potential study.
textPassages.study_title: Experiences Using Systematic Review Guidelines
textPassages.study_authors: Staples,  Mark and Niazi,  Mahmood

practiceInstances.description: Describe quality assessment mechanisms as part of the protocol

textPassages.text: Description of quality assessment mechanisms as part of the protocol, to evaluate each study.
textPassages.study_title: Experiences Using Systematic Review Guidelines
textPassages.study_authors: Staples,  Mark and Niazi,  Mahmood

practiceInstances.description: Describe review and cross-checking processes as part of the protocol to control researcher bias

textPassages.text: Description of review and cross-checking processes as part of the protocol, and involving multiple independent researchers, in order to control researcher bias
textPassages.study_title: Experiences Using Systematic Review Guidelines
textPassages.study_authors: Staples,  Mark and Niazi,  Mahmood

practiceInstances.description: Record the specific search string used for each resource

textPassages.text: There are alternative search strategies that enable you to achieve different sort of search completion criteria. You must select and justify a search strategy that is appropriate for your research question.
textPassages.study_title: Experiences Using Systematic Review Guidelines
textPassages.study_authors: Staples,  Mark and Niazi,  Mahmood

practiceInstances.description: Record data definitions and data extraction guidelines in the protocol

textPassages.text: Data extraction is assisted by having data definitions and data extraction guidelines form the protocol recorded in a separate short document.
textPassages.study_title: Experiences Using Systematic Review Guidelines
textPassages.study_authors: Staples,  Mark and Niazi,  Mahmood

practiceInstances.description: Provide guidance on classification and summarization of qualitative information in protocols

textPassages.text: it may be beneficial for the guidelines to provide more guidance on the classification and summarization of qualitative information, and the positioning of these activities within systematic review protocols.
textPassages.study_title: Experiences Using Systematic Review Guidelines
textPassages.study_authors: Staples,  Mark and Niazi,  Mahmood

practiceInstances.description: Report only the final protocol design and provide commentary on changes made

textPassages.text: suggest that in the full reporting of a systematic review only the final (fake) protocol design be shown together with footnotes or other supplementary commentary that discuss the nature and reason of any changes made to the initial protocol during the course of the systematic review.
textPassages.study_title: Experiences Using Systematic Review Guidelines
textPassages.study_authors: Staples,  Mark and Niazi,  Mahmood

keyPractices.description: Publish a full report separately from a journal overview paper when reporting systematic reviews

textPassages.text: we have provided the full report as an institutional technical report (Niazi and Staples, 2006), and are preparing a separate journal paper that will include an overview of the methodology and results of the systematic review. We believe this a satisfactory approach for reporting systematic reviews.
textPassages.study_title: Experiences Using Systematic Review Guidelines
textPassages.study_authors: Staples,  Mark and Niazi,  Mahmood

keyPractices.description: Keep a detailed record of all decisions made during the review process and report them

textPassages.text: Review teams need to keep a detailed record of decisions made throughout the review process, but we would amplify this and claim that these decisions must also be reported.
textPassages.study_title: Experiences Using Systematic Review Guidelines
textPassages.study_authors: Staples,  Mark and Niazi,  Mahmood

keyPractices.description: Concentrate on checklist items that relate to good reporting rather than good experimental procedures

textPassages.text: Concentrate on checklist items that relate to good reporting rather than good experimental procedures
textPassages.study_title: An Evaluation of Quality Checklist Proposals - A participant-observer case study
textPassages.study_authors: Kitchenham,  Barbara A. and Brereton,  O. Pearl and Budgen,  David and Li,  Zhi

keyPractices.description: Justify every action taken in the review and think critically about the process

textPassages.text: You should have good reasons for everything you do; you should be willing to do it. Don’t stop thinking, and be very careful about what you’re doing
textPassages.study_title: Systematic literature reviews in software engineering: Preliminary results from interviews with researchers
textPassages.study_authors: Babar,  Muhammad Ali and Zhang,  He

keyPractices.description: Clarify search, selection, and quality criteria as thoroughly as possible

textPassages.text: Clarify criteria for search, selection and quality as much as you can, and as good as you can
textPassages.study_title: Systematic literature reviews in software engineering: Preliminary results from interviews with researchers
textPassages.study_authors: Babar,  Muhammad Ali and Zhang,  He

Dimensions.Description: This dimension ensures that the design and planning adopted is carefully aligned with the review goals to comply its objective

keyPractices.description: Collect data in a way that addresses the research issue

textPassages.text: Was the data collected in a way that addressed the research issue?
textPassages.study_title: Quality assessment of systematic reviews in software engineering: a tertiary study
textPassages.study_authors: Zhou,  You and Zhang,  He and Huang,  Xin and Yang,  Song and Babar,  Muhammad Ali and Tang,  Hao

practiceInstances.description: Define study metrics, methods, and measures clearly in study design

textPassages.text: Are the metrics (methods, design, measures) used in the study clearly (fully) defined (description)?
textPassages.study_title: Quality assessment of systematic reviews in software engineering: a tertiary study
textPassages.study_authors: Zhou,  You and Zhang,  He and Huang,  Xin and Yang,  Song and Babar,  Muhammad Ali and Tang,  Hao

textPassages.text: Are the metrics used in the study the most relevant ones for answering the research questions?
textPassages.study_title: Quality assessment of systematic reviews in software engineering: a tertiary study
textPassages.study_authors: Zhou,  You and Zhang,  He and Huang,  Xin and Yang,  Song and Babar,  Muhammad Ali and Tang,  Hao

keyPractices.description: Apply search strategy aligned with research aims

textPassages.text: Was the recruitment strategy appropriate to the aims of the research?
textPassages.study_title: Quality assessment of systematic reviews in software engineering: a tertiary study
textPassages.study_authors: Zhou,  You and Zhang,  He and Huang,  Xin and Yang,  Song and Babar,  Muhammad Ali and Tang,  Hao

keyPractices.description: Use research design appropriate to the study aims

textPassages.text: Was the research design appropriate to address the aims of the research?
textPassages.study_title: Quality assessment of systematic reviews in software engineering: a tertiary study
textPassages.study_authors: Zhou,  You and Zhang,  He and Huang,  Xin and Yang,  Song and Babar,  Muhammad Ali and Tang,  Hao

textPassages.text: Is the methodology (design) used suitable to address the stated research questions?
textPassages.study_title: Quality assessment of systematic reviews in software engineering: a tertiary study
textPassages.study_authors: Zhou,  You and Zhang,  He and Huang,  Xin and Yang,  Song and Babar,  Muhammad Ali and Tang,  Hao

keyPractices.description: Ensure study contributes value to research or practice

textPassages.text: Is the study of value for research or practice?
textPassages.study_title: Quality assessment of systematic reviews in software engineering: a tertiary study
textPassages.study_authors: Zhou,  You and Zhang,  He and Huang,  Xin and Yang,  Song and Babar,  Muhammad Ali and Tang,  Hao

keyPractices.description: Define complementary research questions to clarify the main questions

textPassages.text: We suggest that complementary research questions can help clarify the main questions and define selection criteria.
textPassages.study_title: Experiences Using Systematic Review Guidelines
textPassages.study_authors: Staples,  Mark and Niazi,  Mahmood

textPassages.text: We also found that it was very helpful to define complementary research questions that were not being investigated, so as to clarify the boundaries of our research question of interest.
textPassages.study_title: Experiences Using Systematic Review Guidelines
textPassages.study_authors: Staples,  Mark and Niazi,  Mahmood

practiceInstances.description: Identify the unit of analysis (i.e. to be explicitly clear whether you are studying organizations, teams, or individuals) explicitly when defining research questions

textPassages.text: an instance of our recommendation to define complementary research questions is to clearly identify the unit of analysis for the research question, i.e. to be explicitly clear whether you are studying organizations, teams, or individuals.
textPassages.study_title: Experiences Using Systematic Review Guidelines
textPassages.study_authors: Staples,  Mark and Niazi,  Mahmood

keyPractices.description: Perform a pilot test in the SLR protocol

textPassages.text: Conduct a pilot review, especially when unfamiliar with the domain
textPassages.study_title: Systematic literature reviews in software engineering: Preliminary results from interviews with researchers
textPassages.study_authors: Babar,  Muhammad Ali and Zhang,  He

practiceInstances.description: Pilot aspects of the protocol during its development

textPassages.text: Kitchenham recommends in several places that aspects of the protocol should be piloted during its development.
textPassages.study_title: Experiences Using Systematic Review Guidelines
textPassages.study_authors: Staples,  Mark and Niazi,  Mahmood

practiceInstances.description: Review the protocol itself because it is critical for the systematic review

textPassages.text: Review the protocol itself because it is critical for the systematic review.
textPassages.study_title: Experiences Using Systematic Review Guidelines
textPassages.study_authors: Staples,  Mark and Niazi,  Mahmood

practiceInstances.description: Pilot the research protocol to find mistakes and refine the methodology

textPassages.text: Piloting the research protocol is essential. It will find mistakes in your data collection and aggregation procedures. It may also indicate that you need to change the methodology you intend to use to address the research questions.
textPassages.study_title: Experiences Using Systematic Review Guidelines
textPassages.study_authors: Staples,  Mark and Niazi,  Mahmood

practiceInstances.description: Trial search terms, selection criteria, and data extraction procedures before finalizing the protocol

textPassages.text: the search terms, selection criteria, and data extraction procedures should all be trialled before finalising the protocol.
textPassages.study_title: Experiences Using Systematic Review Guidelines
textPassages.study_authors: Staples,  Mark and Niazi,  Mahmood

keyPractices.description: Use a formal search strategy to identify all relevant publications

textPassages.text: A formal search strategy (described in the protocol) is used to find the entire population of publications that may be relevant to the research questions.
textPassages.study_title: Experiences Using Systematic Review Guidelines
textPassages.study_authors: Staples,  Mark and Niazi,  Mahmood

keyPractices.description: Determine how quality assessment will be used in data aggregation and analysis

textPassages.text: It is important to be sure how the quality assessment will be used in the subsequent data aggregation and analysis.
textPassages.study_title: Experiences Using Systematic Review Guidelines
textPassages.study_authors: Staples,  Mark and Niazi,  Mahmood

keyPractices.description: Revise research questions during protocol development as understanding increases

textPassages.text: Expect to revise your questions during protocol development, as your understanding of the problem increases experiences with the revision of research questions during systematic review.
textPassages.study_title: Experiences Using Systematic Review Guidelines
textPassages.study_authors: Staples,  Mark and Niazi,  Mahmood

keyPractices.description: Modify EBSE guidance for students and novice researchers to include developing a well-defined research question

textPassages.text: The EBSE guidance should be modified for students and novice researchers to incorporate the process of developing a well-defined research question.
textPassages.study_title: Preliminary Reporting Guidelines for Experience Papers
textPassages.study_authors: Budgen,  David and Zhang,  Cheng

keyPractices.description: Define a search strategy early, but allow for its adjustment and reporting during the review

textPassages.text: EBSE guidelines state that the review protocol should be defined in advance (Kitchenham 2004), but in practice this is also often very difficult to achieve. The search strategy is likely to be adjusted as the results are inspected and the research question evolves, so that the process of adjustment and refinement should be included in the reporting of the systematic review
textPassages.study_title: Preliminary Reporting Guidelines for Experience Papers
textPassages.study_authors: Budgen,  David and Zhang,  Cheng

keyPractices.description: Adapt the SLR process to support novices through stepwise guidance and iterative cycles rather than expecting a linear, expert-driven review

practiceInstances.description: Start with a broad question and refine it iteratively as the search progresses

textPassages.text: Using the initial question ‘What has been published already on Topic X?’ gave students a starting point. In most cases the number of results returned was initially too high. Setting a target number of results for analysis and requiring documentation of the process made students persevere with their search, usually by narrowing down to a more focussed research question and more sophisticated search strategies.
textPassages.study_title: Preliminary Reporting Guidelines for Experience Papers
textPassages.study_authors: Budgen,  David and Zhang,  Cheng

practiceInstances.description: Allow for iterative refinement of the protocol rather than treating the protocol as fixed

textPassages.text: “EBSE guidelines state that the review protocol should be defined in advance (Kitchenham 2004), but in practice this is also often very difficult to achieve. The search strategy is likely to be adjusted as the results are inspected and the research question evolves, so that the process of adjustment and refinement should be included in the reporting of the systematic review.”
textPassages.study_title: Preliminary Reporting Guidelines for Experience Papers
textPassages.study_authors: Budgen,  David and Zhang,  Cheng

keyPractices.description: Read general guidelines as a starting point and use more detailed ones for specific research areas

textPassages.text: Advocates suggested reading any general guidelines as a starting point, and then using “more detailed guidelines for specific areas (where) your interest is and relevant
textPassages.study_title: Systematic literature reviews in software engineering: Preliminary results from interviews with researchers
textPassages.study_authors: Babar,  Muhammad Ali and Zhang,  He

textPassages.text: Read the guidelines, e.g. Kitchenham’s guidelines, make sure your understand, and then follow the guidelines; but never expect the guidelines give all answers to the problems, 43
textPassages.study_title: Systematic literature reviews in software engineering: Preliminary results from interviews with researchers
textPassages.study_authors: Babar,  Muhammad Ali and Zhang,  He

Dimensions.Description: This dimension handles all aspects related to optimization of SLR process to make it less costly in terms of time and effort needed.

keyPractices.description: Define research questions clearly and narrowly to reduce effort and improve selection and data extraction

textPassages.text: We recommend researchers clearly and narrowly define research questions to reduce overall effort, and to improve selection and data extraction.
textPassages.study_title: Experiences Using Systematic Review Guidelines
textPassages.study_authors: Staples,  Mark and Niazi,  Mahmood

textPassages.text: Make your research questions as concrete and explicit as possible, keep focus on them and a narrow world. Don’t waste lots of time on irrelevant literature
textPassages.study_title: Systematic literature reviews in software engineering: Preliminary results from interviews with researchers
textPassages.study_authors: Babar,  Muhammad Ali and Zhang,  He

keyPractices.description: Form an SLR team of three people to balance bias avoidance and coordination effort

textPassages.text: In addition, two followers recommended the ideal team size for SLR is to get three people involved. If less, it might be difficult to avoid subjective bias; if more, it may take much time and effort in communication, coordination and getting agreement, particularly in a distributed working environment., 38
textPassages.study_title: Systematic literature reviews in software engineering: Preliminary results from interviews with researchers
textPassages.study_authors: Babar,  Muhammad Ali and Zhang,  He

keyPractices.description: Allocate adequate time for protocol development and anticipate revisions
Validate your protocol externally to reduce rework

textPassages.text: Get your protocol validated externally, as a low-quality protocol may lead to a lot of rework
textPassages.study_title: Systematic literature reviews in software engineering: Preliminary results from interviews with researchers
textPassages.study_authors: Babar,  Muhammad Ali and Zhang,  He
